abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Agricultural Sector
            Management Project for Kenya was satisfactory. The project
            achieved its core objectives, its impact on institutional
            development was substantial, sustainability is uncertain,
            and the performance of both the Bank and Borrower was
            satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, the project clearly demonstrates the need
            for a carefully designed, comprehensive institutional
            development plan, accompanied by a pragmatic implementation
            strategy. In its absence, capacity building could end up as
            a non-sustainable ad hoc exercise. Second, while TA is an
            essential ingredient for getting institutional strengthening
            measures underway, the socio-political climate and policy
            environment should be carefully weighed and factored in at
            the time of designing a project. Third, the comprehensive
            and effective reform of the public sector, including the
            civil service, is essential for supporting development
            interventions such as ASMP. Fourth, as budget
            rationalization is an on-going process, measures to improve
            the budgetary process and overall quality of the budget have
            to constantly be instituted. Fifth, for projects containing
            a substantial training component, there should be a clear
            assignment of responsibilities for the implementation of the
            training program, with special attention given to the
            design. Finally, project implementation arrangements should
            be reviewed periodically.
